DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House serious issues of maladministration concerning the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and relating to Mr John Scott Holloway. I have previously brought to the attention of the House Mr Holloway's deviant sexual proclivities. I wish to emphasise that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Evans) was aware of Mr Holloway's proclivities and indeed sought a belated assurance from Mr Holloway, prior to his appointment to a key position in Cambodia, that he would desist from such activities.

PARA.TAB: I refer now to a mystery that has become a secret. One must ask whether Senator Evans may have misled the Senate in August 1983 concerning the leaking of the Austeo papers—the name given to Australia's most sensitive intelligence documents leaked to the National Times in May 1983. The leaked documents were the crown jewels of Australian intelligence classified `Top secret', `Oyster', `Austeo' and from ASIS, ONA, DSD, ASIO and the most sensitive sections of the Hope Royal Commission into Intelligence and Security. The then Labor government was so concerned that it sought a High Court injunction at 11.15 at night to prevent further publication of documents.
Senator Evans, in his then capacity as Attorney-General, said on page 132 of the Hansard of 24 August 1983 in reply to a question from Senator Austin Lewis:

SPEECH.PARA: When information comes to light as a result of those investigations, no doubt it will be made public in the ordinary and proper way.

It was not. Why not? Can we seriously believe that the combined forces of ASIO and the AFP could not identify the source of the leak of the Austeo papers after an investigation lasting six months? Of course, they could and did.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans, DFAT, the ubiquitous Michael Costello and the then foreign minister, Bill Hayden, swung into damage control mode. For investigations had revealed that the source of the leaks known as the Austeo papers was a senior DFAT officer, Mr John Holloway. It was Mr Holloway who, in a fit of pique concerning failure to obtain a diplomatic position he sought, passed the Austeo papers to a leading newspaper editor and it was Mr Holloway who had been placed under surveillance by police during visits to two capital cities.

This is the man chosen by Senator Evans and the present DFAT secretary, Michael Costello, for a vital role in rebuilding Cambodia in the Costello sponsored peace plan. We now find Senator Evans and Mr Michael Costello, the secretary to DFAT, according to DFAT administrative circular dated 10 August 1995, file No. 94/020051, confirming:

SPEECH.PARA: In accordance with Senator Evans's wishes Mr Holloway will remain in his current appointment as ministerial adviser with the Cambodia ministry of foreign affairs and international cooperation.
A mushroom cloud of corruption and nepotism hovers over DFAT. Many staff want an inquiry into its secretary and overall management. It is now a matter of national honour.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I point out that it was Mr Costello who was reported in the media on 7 June as saying that he had not been responsible for the promotion or appointment of any known paedophile in the department, yet that administrative circular that I referred to otherwise states. I seek leave to table the circular.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —This week we saw the member for Moore (Mr Filing) sit in the parliament as an Independent. This followed his brutal de-selection as the endorsed Liberal candidate for the federal seat of Moore at the next election at the hands of the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party. Let us see the responses that we got to that.

PARA.TAB: The Australian writes, `MP's resignation highlights Liberal divisions.' An editorial in the Australian, headed `Howard's unresolved WA problem', refers to the `obvious helplessness' of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and his `inability to resolve the factional war that continues to tear apart the Liberal Party in Western Australia'. The Australian Financial Review writes, `WA disarray as Liberal MP quits.' An article in the Age headed `Liberals face more defections after Filing' provides an interesting further development of this matter.
In an article in the Australian headed `MP's resignation highlights Liberal party divisions', we find references to `deep divisions' in the Liberal Party. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Filing's resignation . . . is an embarrassment to the Leader of the Opposition . . .
It continues:
Mr Filing told Mr Howard that he would continue to vote for and support the Coalition in the House of Representatives.
Mr Greenlees writes in the Australian:

PARA.TAB: Mr Filing's decision . . . highlighted the woeful state of non-Labor policies in Western Australia.
He will act as a reminder of the inability of the federal party to manage the divisions in its West Australian branch.
This decision . . . underlined Howard's impotence in the face of the internecine struggle in Western Australia.
Filing presents indisputable evidence to West Australian voters that the State branch—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, of the Liberal Party—
is wracked by conflict.

In the West Australian of Tuesday, 20 June 1995 there is reference to a Mr Simon Ehrenfeld, who is the president of the Young Liberal Movement in Western Australia and the campaign director of the endorsed Liberal candidate for Moore, Mr Paul Stevenage. In this article, reference is made to the Young Liberal Movement, which is described as follows:

Set up by Liberal patriarch Robert Menzies in 1945, officially its objects are, "To support and promote the objects, policy and platform of the movement and the party," and "to provide political, educational, social, sporting and community activities for young people".

I wonder whether Mr Ehrenfeld, the president of the Western Australian Young Liberal Movement, was acting in accordance with the objectives and platform of the Young Liberal Movement when he rang Mr Alistaer Jones on 6 June. Mr Jones is the endorsed Labor candidate for the seat of Moore. In the course of that conversation, Mr Ehrenfeld identified himself as the campaign director for Paul Stevenage, the endorsed Liberal candidate for the seat of Moore. Mr Ehrenfeld said that he was seeking to develop a `put Filing last' campaign. Mr Ehrenfeld raised the question of ALP preferences with the ALP candidate, Mr Alistaer Jones, and was quite correctly told by Mr Jones that that was a matter for the state or national secretary of the ALP.

PARA.TAB: In the course of the conversation, Mr Ehrenfeld described the honourable member for Moore as poison. Mr Ehrenfeld said that he, as campaign director for the endorsed Liberal candidate for Moore and president of the Young Liberal Movement of Western Australia, would rather see the ALP candidate in parliament than the present member for Moore.

In the course of the conversation, it was not only the seat of Moore that was discussed; the seat of Cowan was also referred to. Mr Ehrenfeld told Mr Jones that Liberal Party polling suggested that the Labor candidate, Carolyn Jakobsen, was ahead of the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) and that, if the member for Cowan did not improve over the next three months, he might not be there as a candidate at the next election.

What do we have? Here we have in substantive terms the campaign director for the endorsed Liberal candidate for Moore and the president of the Young Liberal Movement in Western Australia saying that he would rather see in the parliament a Labor member for the seat of Moore than the current member for Moore, Mr Filing, who is known to be one of the strongest supporters of the Leader of the Opposition in this place. That is a view which we on this side of the House agree with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as you are aware, each year I bring two students to Canberra as part of an ongoing scholarship scheme held with the cooperation of the high schools within the electorate of O'Connor. I would like to take this opportunity to thank Ansett Australia Airlines for its kind assistance in supporting this scholarship scheme.

PARA.TAB: This year I have brought the 37th and 38th students, and I am pleased to say that they are both in the Speaker's gallery tonight. They are Kerry Gorski from John Willcock Senior High School in Geraldton and Michael Parnell from the Cunderdin Agricultural College. Michael is a resident of the Perth suburb of Melville. Both Karen and Michael have written short speeches about the area in which they live and/or the school they attend. I wish to read these speeches into the Hansard.

Karen Gorski writes that Geraldton was founded by Charles Fitzgerald and is 424 kilometres north of Perth. Situated in the mid-west, it has a thriving sheep and wheat industry. Due to its proximity to the coast, it is the centre for Western Australia's fishing and crayfishing industry. The famous wreck of the Dutch ship the Batavia in 1629 has led to the coastal regions surrounding Geraldton being known as the Batavia Coast.

With a population of 24,000, Geraldton welcomes the flood of tourists that visit each year for its warm climate and beautiful beaches. The region is well known for its abundance of wild flowers throughout July and August. Many people also visit the area to see the Greenough Hamlet, a national heritage site which comprises restored buildings dating from the first settlers to the area. The high winds that have given Geraldton an international windsurfing reputation are the cause of the remarkable bent trees that one sees in this Greenough region. The annual sunshine and performing arts festivals are held in September and November.

Established in 1975, the John Willcock Senior High School has approximately 750 students and was named in honour of John Willcock, who was Premier of Western Australia between 1936 and 1945. The school motto is `enlighten' and the purpose of the school is to develop fully a student's academic, social and personal skills, enabling them to become a more productive member of society. The school caters for years 8 to 12 students who have the opportunity to study a range of subjects. Theatre arts is an important aspect of the school, with a production held for the public each year. The school offers a variety of career pathways, with the introduction of skilling through enterprise programs two years ago. Annual events include participation in WA Country Week where sporting and debating teams are sent to compete with other country schools.

Michael Parnell writes that Cunderdin Agricultural College is one of seven agricultural schools in Western Australia and it is situated in the central wheat belt, 160 kilometres east of Perth on the Great Eastern Highway—the main road link between Perth and the eastern states.

The word Cunderdin is derived from an Aboriginal language and means `the place of many flowers'. In the spring months, the Cunderdin area is alive with pink and yellow everlastings, living up to that Aboriginal name.

The site at which the college is situated was previously a World War II flying school which at any one time housed approximately 534 trainee airmen. Many of these airmen participated in the defence of Australia and would currently be involved with the Australia Remembers 1945-95 program, which is, of course, commemorating the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II.

The college is a fully co-educational, residential complex catering for 110 year 11 and year 12 students, who come from all over Western Australia. As I have pointed out, Michael is not a country boy but is, of course, gaining a wonderful education at this college.

Acceptance into the school is based on an interview with the principal and a confidential report from the applicant's previous school. Forty-one students graduated in 1994, including five who have gained certificates of excellence from the Secondary Education Authority of Western Australia. Several graduates gained entry to Muresk Campus of Curtin University, with three winning first-year scholarships. All graduates from 1994 had a commitment to further education, apprenticeships or employment.

Cunderdin College comprises 1,600 hectares of land, some of which is cropped and grazed. The farm consists of a shearing shed, poultry units, slaughterhouse, butcher shop, machinery schools and farm workshops. All of these facilities are used by the students in their education, of which 50 per cent is theory and 50 per cent is practical.

Sport plays a big part in the life of the student at Cunderdin. Sports offered include football, squash, tennis, volleyball, basketball, gun club, hockey, salt lake sailing, netball and badminton. The students of this college have a great life, particularly for those seeking knowledge in the field of agriculture.

The role of agricultural colleges in Western Australia creates good vocational opportunities by teaching practical skills suitable not only to those wishing to enter the agricultural industry but also to those wishing to undertake careers in boilermaking, motor vehicle repairs and many other practical areas of appointment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight on Lebanon. Lebanon is a small country far away from Australia geographically but very close to us in our hearts. Over 100,000 Australians are descended from Lebanon and they have come to Australia to make homes and lives and to contribute. Due to great problems in the Middle East, Lebanon, being basically small and defenceless, has been victimised and made the butt of other people's problems.

PARA.TAB: At the moment, Lebanon is substantially occupied by the Syrian army. The Syrian justification, in their own eyes, is that Lebanon is part of Syria. This claim is rejected by almost every other nation and Lebanon is a country in good standing and legitimacy within the international community. Lebanon is a member of the United Nations.

On 18 July, the Australian government will be reopening its embassy in Beirut. It should never have been closed. I am aware that a fierce civil war raged from 1975 until recently; however, nations cannot turn and run as soon as problems arise. This has caused severe hardship for the citizens of Lebanon. When they have wanted to get visas to visit Australia, they have had to travel to Damascus. Not only did they often incur physical risks, but guards often had to be paid off to ensure safe passage. This situation is intolerable.

Israel also has troops in southern Lebanon. This occupation is due to the use of southern Lebanon to shell towns in northern Israel. This shelling was carried out not by forces of the Lebanese government but by Lebanese agents of Iran and other nations in the area.

Lebanon itself has never engaged in warfare with Israel or any other nation. The Lebanese themselves are not aggressive or warlike. War has been introduced into their country as a result of various serious political crises that have beset the region for the past 50 years.

With the reopening of the embassy in Beirut will come the reopening of the immigration department office in Beirut. As I have previously said, all Lebanese migration matters have gone through Syria. This situation was always unsatisfactory and I trust it will not be repeated.

Despite recent carping about immigration, the cold facts are that, without immigration, Australia's population will decline and age very rapidly. Who will pay for the costs of the retirees and who will provide the domestic market? I notice that in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald the Australian Bureau of Statistics remarked that the number of those who are 65 years and over will have doubled by the year 2041 and will represent 22 per cent of the population.

Over the years, the Lebanese have proved to be excellent migrants and their pride in this country is boundless. The reason for this is that we took them in when they were in difficulty and they have repaid the debt with interest.

The new immigration office will see a renewed interest in immigration. I recently met Dory Chamoun on his recent visit to Australia. He spoke passionately of his belief that Lebanon as we know it may cease to be a nation within 15 years if things continue as they are. He spoke of the desire of many people, especially Christian Maronites, to leave Lebanon. When I asked what Australia could do to help Lebanon, he said that education and skills training were the very important areas where he felt our expertise could be contributed and very much appreciated.

It is impossible to represent an electorate like mine without understanding my constituents' genuine concern for the country of their birth, although they now reside in the country of their choice. The Lebanese who have come to Australia have contributed mightily to our national welfare and if we had more of them Australia would be better off. As any observer of the Middle East will realise, the situation there is very volatile and security is a problem that is very serious for many people.

The talents of people from the Middle East run very strongly to business and commerce and our Australian business presence in the Middle East, especially Lebanon, is minimal. This is unacceptable and, given our large business community of Middle East origin, it is a mystery. As a matter of priority and urgency, the government must engage more rigorously in commerce with the Middle East. Austrade, an excellent Australian instrumentality, should be encouraged to be more active and more aggressive.

Lebanon is a very modern and Westernised country. The capacity for successful Australian-Lebanese business is very high. We also should be involving more Australians of Lebanese descent in this bilateral growth. Australia cannot lose by the ideas I am proposing. Australia should be very grateful that so many Lebanese have come here and are available to help us return to the Middle East for commerce and cultural ties. Australia has a great future, but we must build it and we cannot do this without the help of the Middle East and the people of Lebanon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Mrs B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We learned today that Australia is now worse off than Mexico. This, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has told us, is as good as it is going to get. This is the same Paul Keating who said when he was Treasurer that Mr Howard will wear his leadership like a crown of thorns and that in the parliament he would do everything he could to crucify Mr Howard. This is the same Paul Keating who last week abrogated all reasonable responsibility of leadership in the French nuclear testing crisis.

PARA.TAB: Over a period of time I have become concerned, as have others who have contacted me, for the mental well-being of the Prime Minister. Such was my concern that I spoke with a psychiatrist as to the nature of the problem which the Prime Minister might be suffering. The psychiatrist asked not to be identified for fear of reprisals, but referred me to the Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, and particularly the section entitled `Hypomanic Episode'. The document states, among other things:
The elevated mood of a Hypomanic Episode is described as euphoric, unusually good, cheerful, or high.

SPEECH.PARA: Characteristically, inflated self-esteem, usually at the level of uncritical self-confidence.

The speech of a person with a Hypomanic Episode is often somewhat louder and more rapid than usual, but is not typically difficult to interrupt. It may be full of jokes, puns, plays on words, and irrelevancies.
More worrying is that the document states:
Studies suggest that 5%-15% of individuals with hypomania will ultimately develop a Manic Episode.

It could well be said that the Prime Minister is simply under too much strain in trying to run so many irrelevant issues in order to avoid the fundamental issue; that is, the huge international debt he has given to this nation.

PARA.TAB: I have always said that what this country is being put through is not necessary. I would like the House to consider the following analogy. Take your ordinary household, which used to run with such a profit that you were able to buy shares here and overseas and lend money to others. Then within a few short years your house got into such extraordinary debt you could not even pay the interest on the debt. Every month your debt grows and your children are suffering, but you tell them that they have never had it so good. You discuss everything but the problem and you go to your neighbours, who are flush with money, and tell them they are doing everything wrong and explain to them how to run their households.

You attack your own family and blame everyone but yourself, and while your family suffers you yourself buy expensive Italian suits, French clocks and anything else you please. Shouldn't someone who is very concerned for your welfare, for your own safety, suggest that you might seek help? Our parents worked hard and fought for this country and, indeed, some died for it. We inherited a way of life which was unequalled. We owed little to anyone and the people were then prosperous. But now it is the people who are poor and in debt and the Prime Minister who is rich. It just isn't right.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) has earned herself a spot on Order in the House without doubt and will probably get the nuttiest speech of the week award. I am here to speak about youth training and labour market programs.

PARA.TAB: In the debate on the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill in the last sitting week, the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) expressed the view that he did not think the youth training allowance was going to do anything for young people, and he was particularly critical about the government's labour market programs. In my speech which followed his, I obviously disagreed with him, particularly on the labour market programs, and cited as an illustration the young people who have been through LEAP, the landcare and environment assistance program, in my electorate.

I had the great privilege last week of attending one of many LEAP graduations that I have attended in my electorate. They have all been greatly successful, but this one was of particular gratification to me. In some programs, as with all labour market programs, all training programs and I guess even university degrees, a number of people enrol, start the program and some drop out. In this particular program 11 young people were involved and they were all from the groups known as long-term unemployed or at risk. At the graduation it was a great delight for me to see that 10 of those young people had permanent jobs to go to after six months in that training course.

You may not think that is amazing, but normally you are lucky if half of those young people get jobs. Others may have training opportunities or other connections that they can build on, or they have gained enough self-confidence to go for something else, but 10 of the 11 young people had received jobs. I thought it was eight when I got up to give my speech, but before I left I was told that two more of them had got jobs. Some could not get time off from their jobs to come to the graduation.

One particular young woman who gave what I thought was an excellent thank you speech on behalf of the students—she wrote it herself, showed it to the leader of the group and he thought it was fine—had been unemployed for some time, came from a broken family and had a great deal of difficulties. But she was working and she was proud of the fact that she was working.

I think LEAP is one of the best labour market programs this government, or even previous governments, has ever initiated for three fundamental reasons. Firstly, it gives young people—I know it is a cliche to say that young people are our future—some work training. Secondly, and more importantly, it gives them confidence; it gives them a boost to their self-esteem. I was told that when some of the people first came to the group and had to stand up and say their names and where they were from one of them was so nervous she just rushed out of the room, and there she was at this group—very confident and very self-assured. The third reason why LEAP is so successful is that it deals with the environment. It is providing job training, self-confidence and helping the environment.

In my electorate the environment is extremely important. As most members will know, the area in my electorate covers the Blue Mountains and the Hawkesbury area. We have the Hawkesbury-Nepean river system, which is in need of a great deal of care. We have national parks, bush reserves and areas that need assistance to regenerate, to remove weeds and so on. Some of the programs that have been carried out under LEAP are under the auspices of Greening Australia. I pay great tribute to Greening Australia as a wonderful organisation that does a fantastic on-the-ground job with the environment.

LEAP has done such things as removing weeds and creating, out of an absolute mess, a reserve and walking track along the banks of the Hawkesbury River at Swallow Rock Reach reserve. It has cleaned up a lagoon in the Blue Mountains and created a reserve. The latest program that I mentioned created, out of a swamp, a recreational lake with picnic areas and walking tracks. It is a wonderful place for people who live in the Bligh Park area, which is a huge new housing estate, to go to and enjoy themselves.

LEAP and also REEP, of which this latest project was a part, are highly successful. The pilot REEP project in New South Wales is based in the Hawkesbury-Nepean catchment. I am very proud that that was chosen in my electorate and several other members' electorates to be the first to deal with that sort of work. I commend the program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I represented, for some 20 years, the state electorate of what was then called Flinders. We were able to secure infrastructure for that area, which was unprecedented.
—When are you going to apologise to the people of Queensland for your corruption?

—I absolutely love interjections of this type. I am very short of time so I suppose I should run on, but I cannot help but go sideways. The amount of $26 million of public moneys was spent, of which $26,000 went astray in the state of Queensland. I would say that inquiry proved we were the most honest government in all of Australian history. The inquiry looked under our toenails and found that $26,000 of public money had gone astray after $26 million had been spent. In sharp contrast, in Western Australia $876,000 went astray and in South Australia $3,000 million went astray. We handed over the best economically run state in the Commonwealth. Not only did it prove our honesty and decency but we pursued, even to the destruction of our own government, police corruption. We found out the corrupt police and we put them in gaol.
—And who was it who was corrupt? Your minister.

—You might drag me sideways on Shoalwater Bay again. I would enjoy talking about how a man bought something that was worth absolutely nothing and then got $2 million off Mr Goss. So be careful and don't provoke me.

PARA.TAB: In Charters Towers, the magistrate and the state government geological office, the functions of which had been there for over 100 years, were removed by the government. At a time when Charters Towers is the biggest it has ever been, it had both of those services removed. At a time when it is the third richest gold producing city in Australia, it had those services removed.

The assistance to schools has been cut in half in Queensland, whereas in 1987 and 1988 you could get all of the money you required from the government to go away to boarding school. All of the families in the mid-west towns, the towns west of Charters Towers—none of which have secondary school facilities that enable you to go on to universities—could get the government to pick up the cost of sending their kids away to school.

The cut in assistance has cost Charters Towers greatly. The schools there have lost enrolments because people are not able to send their kids to those schools. Far more seriously, the western towns in Queensland no longer have any equality in education. Families in those towns simply cannot afford to send their kids away to school. As cheap and as reasonable as those schools in Charters Towers are and as excellent as the service in those schools is, it costs $10,000 a year to send your child away to school, but now you get only $5,000 out of the $10,000.

The four little towns between Charters Towers and Hughenden—Balfes Creek, Torrens Creek, Pentland and Prairie—have all lost their railway stations. In fact, Torrens Creek has lost the railway station, the police station and the school. Pentland's meatworks closed down, with the loss of 300 jobs to the area. I am very proud to say that I was heavily involved with the AMIU in keeping the meatworks open for that time.

Hughenden has lost the railway control room, with over 20 jobs gone. Half the diesel workshops are closed, with over 20 jobs gone. The clerk of the court is gone. The industrial office is gone. The lands office, I am informed, is also gone. Richmond has lost a full-time doctor and the clerk of the court is gone. Julia Creek has lost its high school completely. It has also lost its clerk of the court. Greenvale's railway line has been closed and torn up, losing all of the jobs involved with it. It was a great facility and asset to the area. ANSWER.PARA: Department of the House of Representatives
The Department of the House of Representatives has engaged the services of the Employee
Assistance Service ACT (EASACT), formerly the Industrial Program Service, on a continuing basis since 1 November 1989.

PARA.TAB: (a)The service was engaged to provide short term professional, impartial and confidential face to face and telephone counselling to departmental staff and their immediate families on a wide range of personal and work related concerns.
(b)The current annual contract with EASACT for the year 1 November 1994 to 31 October 1995 is $7,000.

PARA.TAB: (d)For many years it has been acknowledged that departments rarely have the capacity to deal, in a professional and coherent way, with the range of problems which affect staff and their work performance. Although some larger departments have employed welfare officers/counsellors, this is not a viable or cost efficient and effective option for an agency the size of the Department of the House of Representatives. Moreover, staff often doubt the confidentiality of the services and the welfare officer/counsellor can have difficulty in reconciling his or her management advising role. The Employee Assistance Service was seen as providing effective, cost efficient, responsive and minimum intervention services to staff for work and family related problems. The service also reinforces one of our departmental values that the staff of the department are its most valuable asset.
In October 1993 a review was completed of the employee assistance program using the following evaluation criteria agreed by the departmental occupational health and safety committee:
usage rates of the service by staff and eligible relatives;
feedback from staff and supervisors and unions and their expectations;
cost benefit analysis of the current premium structure against a fee for service arrangement, and
the views and practices of other agencies, particularly the other parliamentary departments.

it is well regarded by staff, supervisors and unions, although support is not overt;
it provides a valuable service to the department in terms of human resource management and OH&S principles, and
the contract rate is cost effective compared to an appropriate fee for service approach.

BETWEEN: THE DEPARTMENT OF THE SENATE ("The Client") of the one part and EMPLOYEE ASSISTANCE SERVICE (ACT) LIMITED ("EAS") of the other part.
A.EAS has agreed to provide certain employee assistance services to the client.
B.EAS has developed a program in consultation with the client to provide for the specific needs of the client's employees and their immediate families ("the Program").
C.The parties wish to set down the terms of the agreement.
NOW IT IS HEREBY AGREED as follows:
1.This Agreement shall commence on the first day of August 1990 and end on the thirty-first day of July 1991.

2.This Agreement may be terminated at any time by either party giving ninety (90) days written notice to the other ("the notice period"). On the day of expiry of the notice period, this agreement is thereby terminated. Upon such termination the fee paid by the client shall be calculated pro rata to the nearest month and any balance shall be refunded to the client. This agreement may be extended by a written agreement of the parties.
3.EAS shall provide the following services, as required:

PARA.TAB: (a)continued consultancy regarding the Program, including the overall design, development, management and implementation of the program.
(b)individual counselling and case management including:

TAB.TAB: (i)counselling of the employees and family members until an appropriate referral to a helping agency can be made;
(ii)assessment counselling to determine type of referral necessary;
(iii)referral to an appropriate facility or helping agency where appropriate;
(iv)short-term counselling of employees (and family members where involved) where a referral is not appropriate;
(v)monitoring the employees' progress to ensure that they are receiving assistance/treatment that most effectively meets their needs.
(vi)trauma emergency counselling for additional fee per clause 9(v).

PARA.TAB: (c)liaison between the client and all counselling and helping agencies that serve the client's employees and their families in matters related to the Program;

(d)assistance with continuous and ongoing inservice training of the client management and supervisory staff as required by the client. Additional fees will be charged at a per diem rate for all training;
(e)assistance in providing information about the Program to the client's employees through pamphlets, posters and other appropriate means;
(f)ongoing monitoring and reporting on the EAS counselling service, sufficient to enable the client to gauge its effectiveness; and
(g)ongoing formal recommendations for the upgrading and improvement of the Program, including the development of an annual report on program results.

ANSWER.PARA: 4.The client shall furnish announcement brochures, posters and information pamphlets as required by the Program. All such material mentioning EAS must receive the approval of the EAS manager prior to distribution or display.

5.All records of the employees (and family members where involved) maintained by EAS in conjunction with the Program shall be confidential. Employees' records may only be released to the employee upon written request by the employee, and not to any other person, except upon court order.
6.The client has designated. . . . . . as Coordinator of the Program. The Coordinator shall serve as a liaison between EAS and management.

7.Except in emergency, employee services under the Program will be limited to problem assessment, short term counselling and referral. (No additional or ongoing treatment services will be authorised by EAS without consultation and consent of the employee.)

8.EAS agrees and acknowledges that it is acting as an independent contractor. EAS and its employees and agents shall have no authority to incur and shall not incur any obligation of any kind in the name of the client or for its accounts. EAS and its employees and agents shall not act in any way which would give the impression that it has the power or authority to bind the client in any respect whatsoever.

9.(i)In consideration of the services provided for under agreement, the client shall pay EAS $3000 for services as outlined in clause 3(b) hereof for the first year of this agreement. This fee is to be paid upon execution of this agreement.

PARA.TAB: (ii)If this agreement is extended in accordance with clause 2 hereof, the new annual fee shall be agreed between the parties and shall be paid at the commencement of the next twelve month period.

(iii)Training fees of $900 per day or $450 per half day, shall be paid by the client to EAS on the completion of each training session authorised by the client. The client shall pay all transportation and per diem costs incurred by EAS in connection with such training if the work is located outside the Australian Capital Territory.

(iv)If a confirmed training course is cancelled within fourteen (14) days of the agreed date, the charge will be fifty (50) per cent of the quoted per diem rate. If cancelled within 48 hours, the charge will be one hundred (100) per cent of the quoted diem rate.
(v)Trauma counselling fees of $700 per day or $350 per half day shall be paid by the client on completion of each session authorised by the client.

ANSWER.PARA: 10.Failure of either party to require strict performance by the other of any provision of this agreement shall not affect its rights with respect to continued or subsequent breaches.
11.Any notice required by this agreement shall be in writing delivered personally or by registered mail to the last known address of the party being served.

12.This agreement terminates and supersedes any prior oral or written agreements between the parties concerning the Program and constitutes the entire understanding between them. This agreement shall not be changed, modified or varied except by written agreement of the parties.

13.In the event that any part of this agreement is illegal or unenforceable under the law as it is now or hereafter in effect, either party may terminate this agreement immediately upon written notice. Unless terminated the parties shall be excused from performance of such portion or portions of this agreement as shall be found to be illegal or unenforceable without affecting the validity of the remaining provisions of this agreement. This agreement shall be construed in accordance with the internal laws of the Australian Capital Territory.
14The program will be serviced by EAS-ACT for the client at its offices in the Australian Capital Territory.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins) took the chair at 10.00 a.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY PAY-ROLL TAX) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 2 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: From 1971 to 1 August 1987, payroll tax on wages relating to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) were collected by the Commonwealth under the terms of the Pay-roll Tax (Territories) Assessment Act 1971.

PARA.TAB: When the ACT self-government commenced, legislation was not put in place to make these Commonwealth authorities liable for ACT payroll tax. This bill will rectify this situation, and will make those Commonwealth authorities operating in the ACT liable to pay ACT payroll tax in the same way that they are liable to pay state and Northern Territory payroll tax.

The bill applies only to those Commonwealth authorities which, immediately before the commencement of the ACT payroll tax regime, were registered as employers, or had an application for registration pending, under the payroll tax regime of the Commonwealth or of a state or territory. It will have no application to other Commonwealth authorities.

Exempting provisions which would otherwise operate to exclude liability to ACT payroll tax are made inapplicable to those Commonwealth authorities. Those Commonwealth authorities that have paid ACT payroll tax before royal assent to the bill cannot recover the payments.
This legislation will ensure consistency of treatment of Commonwealth authorities between the states and territories.
I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Committee that members of a parliamentary delegation from Botswana are present in the gallery. On behalf of the Committee, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY PAY-ROLL TAX) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has pointed out, the Commonwealth Authorities (Australian Capital Territory Pay-roll Tax) Bill 1995 applies to Commonwealth authorities that were registered or had application to be registered as employers under state, territory or Commonwealth payroll tax acts prior to 1 August 1987. The bill provides that such authorities are subject to the ACT Payroll Tax Act which came into effect on 1 August 1987, even though their establishing acts may confer a general exemption against state or territory taxation. It provides that, where regulations made pursuant to the act establishing the authority have the effect of making it subject to payroll tax of the Commonwealth, a state or a territory, it is subject to the ACT Payroll Tax Act 1987.

PARA.TAB: Subject to one qualification where we seek further clarification, the coalition is not opposed to the bill. The ACT Payroll Tax Act commenced operation on 1 August 1987 and the bill is designed to make it clear that it applies to Commonwealth authorities as defined in the legislation. As the Assistant Treasurer pointed out, apparently some Commonwealth authorities operating in the ACT paid payroll tax to the Australian Capital Territory government assuming that its payroll tax legislation applied to them, even though they might have been entitled to a general exemption on state or territory tax. The effect of the bill is to preclude them from recovering these moneys.Clause 6 of the bill provides:

SPEECH.PARA: A Commonwealth authority that has paid tax payable under the Payroll Tax Act 1987 of the Australian Capital Territory cannot recover those payments if they were made before the commencement of this Act.
The aim of clause 6 is to protect previous collections of payroll tax by the ACT government and avoid the adverse impact that refunds would have on ACT revenues.

PARA.TAB: The bill is necessary to implement the power of the ACT government to levy payroll tax on these Commonwealth authorities. The bill affects only government authorities and I am informed that no private company would be adversely affected by this legislation. The adverse impact of the revenues on the ACT government, if it had to repay the payroll tax to certain authorities, could be considerable, especially as this is a situation which the current government of the ACT has inherited from its predecessor.

If tax were refunded, the ACT would lose, Commonwealth authorities would gain, and no doubt a claim for the reimbursement would in turn be made by the ACT on the Commonwealth. Our query with one aspect of this legislation is with the use of the words `tax payable' in clause 6 of the bill. It may be argued that—and it has been suggested to us—although the authorities paid tax, it was not tax payable by operation of law prior to the commencement of this bill. Therefore, a legal question arises as to whether a reference in this bill to tax payable has the effect, which is intended, of precluding the recovery of moneys if it was not tax payable under an authorised legislative instrument prior to the commencement of this bill.

We are not going to stand in the way—even if we could—of the passage of this bill through the House. However, I have raised the matter with the Assistant Treasurer. I expect that it is not a matter to which he can give an immediate answer at this stage. If it cannot be adequately answered, we will seek to ask the Senate standing committee on legal and constitutional affairs to look at those particular words and that particular clause. We share the concern of the government that the bill, which purports that the money should not be recoverable, will be in fact a binding legislative instrument in the sense that it will not be challenged in the courts in any way and that the spirit of what the government intends is carried into operation. Except for the qualification that I have alluded to, the coalition does not oppose this piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the opposition supports the Commonwealth Authorities (Australian Capital Territory Pay-roll Tax) Bill 1995. It is an important minor piece of legislation for the ACT to guarantee the legislative framework for its revenue base. It makes sense that the Commonwealth, as well as the private sector, should pay these kinds of taxes. In fact, the private sector sometimes complains that Commonwealth instrumentalities are not covered by tax provisions but this legislation will ensure that.

PARA.TAB: The bill is entirely non-controversial and does not deserve debate for more than a moment or two. I would like to use the opportunity to talk briefly about payroll tax in total. Payroll tax is really quite a perverse tax at a time when we have high unemployment. It is a tax on employment. Payroll tax is a discouragement to employment at a time when one of the government's highest priorities, and, I do not doubt, one of the opposition's highest priorities, is to increase employment. We should be aiming in every way possible to reduce or even eliminate payroll tax. Of course, it is a state and territory tax, as is now quite clear from this legislation, so it is not something over which the Commonwealth has direct control. However, the Commonwealth could create conditions under which it was possible for the states and territories to reduce or eliminate payroll tax if other revenue sources were available.

It is very speculative to talk in these terms, but it is important to speculate because we have to try to find ways of consistently and comprehensively creating the conditions in which growth of employment could be maximised. The elimination of payroll tax would be a very significant contribution to that goal. In order to eliminate payroll tax, we would have to find some other comparable source of revenue to replace it. It is a major source of revenue for the states and territories but there are other such sources available. If payroll tax were eliminated then corporate tax collections would rise and they would go to the Commonwealth. That would give the Commonwealth the capacity to increase direct payments to the states, which would, in part, offset the consequences of abolishing payroll tax. I understand that that might offset about a third of the loss of revenue but it would still leave about two-thirds to be found.

One way in which that could be done and which has a lot of appeal to me is the idea of the introduction of some kind of greenhouse gas emission tax. That is a complex, even controversial, proposal because it involves issues relating to the incidence of such a tax which have distributional consequences. But if we want to adopt the general principle of taxing `bads' and reducing taxes on `goods' it makes sense to try to tax greenhouse gas emissions, to discourage those emissions and their polluting effects, whilst reducing tax on employment, which we want to encourage. So I think there is a strong case for a more detailed exploration of the possibility of some kind of greenhouse gas emission tax.

It may well not be a tax that Australia should do alone. It could well be done in conjunction with other industrialised countries and with developing countries as well. That is on the agenda of the European Community, and it may well be on the agenda of other countries as well in due course. I do not think it is an idea that will disappear. It is one that will continue to be explored because there is so much concern about greenhouse gas emissions and that concern is certainly growing. So this possibility is one that we could well explore rather more thoroughly than happened at the beginning of this year. It is certainly one that I would like to see encouraged.

To conclude, I think it is very important that we absolutely minimise payroll tax. While it is right, of course, to apply it to the public sector as well as the private sector, we should be aiming to reduce it so that employment growth is encouraged.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank both the speakers, the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) and the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), for their contribution. The fact that this bill is here in the Main Committee is an indication that it is non-controversial. Both sides agree that the government should act in this way. In response to the matter raised by the member for Menzies on the drafting of clause 6, I can inform him that we will seek advice on that from Attorney-General's. If there is any doubt about the impact that that will have on the payroll tax collection for the ACT, we will amend it in the House. We will try to get that advice before the bill gets back there.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Gear)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.
Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Mr Allan Morris:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick Mr H.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to speak on A report on aspects of youth homelessness. At the outset, I would like to pay tribute to those members of the committee who hung in during the length of this inquiry. It was not easy but I thank them for seeing this report through to the end. I would also like to pay my tribute to Bjarne Nordin and Peta Fitzgibbon for their tireless work during the inquiry and also for their help and guidance so freely offered to committee members. The sheer size of this report would hopefully suggest to those who see it that the committee has come up with a comprehensive and definitive statement regarding this vital issue which now impacts on so many families throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: The committee's terms of reference are worth repeating:

SPEECH.PARA: To inquire into and report to the Parliament on the provision of assistance for homeless youth requiring income support, with particular reference to:

1. the availability of family support and welfare services (including mediation services), their role and effectiveness in reducing homelessness and in resolving differences before young people leave home;

2. the integration of income support provisions for homeless young people with services that assist with family reunion, transition to stable independent living, and opportunities for education, training and employment; and
3. the appropriateness of income support arrangements for homeless young people, noting the need to not create undue incentives to leave home or school.

The issue of youth homelessness is a very emotive one. Stories abound across the length and breadth of this country which highlight the inadequacies of the system which is supposed to strengthen rather than weaken the roles of families in nurturing and supporting their children. The roles of state and federal governments and their various departments have been examined in great detail in this report. Parents, young people and service providers have all given us examples of where the system has failed, and failed dismally. The committee has come up with 129 recommendations for the government to consider. I would like to highlight some of these recommendations and speak briefly to them.

PARA.TAB: At the outset I would like to say that we are facing two problems: firstly, the problem of dealing with the current crop of homeless young people, and, secondly and to my mind a far more important issue, the way in which we must cut off the supply of potential homeless young people by instituting a range of effective programs across state and federal departments to provide support for families and their children. In our report we cover the whole spectrum of homelessness: the historical development of youth income support, the current services for homeless young people and the current income support arrangements for this group. I do not wish to tackle that in my speech here today.

I would like to focus on some of the other aspects of the report. I see these areas as the key to really addressing this vital issue. These areas are: the housing needs of homeless young people; family mediation and counselling services; youth and family policy initiatives; Commonwealth-state responsibilities for the care, support and protection of young people; the role of education; and parental roles and responsibilities.

Firstly, I would like to mention the issue of family mediation and counselling services. This is an area in need of vast improvement across Australia, and more so in the rural and regional areas of our country. It really concerns me that our society still has not come to grips with the realisation of the importance of these valuable services and the need for them to be integrated into all aspects of the life of a family. Like most community services which operate in our country, they are poorly equipped to deal with their case load, are underresourced with staff, usually situated away from their client base, and are the subject of disputation between various state and Commonwealth government departments.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note the comments of the Institute of Family Studies concerning an evaluation of the 11 pilot projects for family mediation set up by the Commonwealth government recently:

The study supports the view that early intervention in situations of family conflict may prevent seemingly ordinary problems from escalating into crisis situations and leaving home with little or no support.
The Attorney-General's Department's comments are also of interest:
The preventative nature of the adolescent mediation and family therapy program means that it is more successful at reaching those clients who have not already left home.

The target population is therefore potentially greater than the number of clients currently receiving homeless rates. Clients attending services are still at home and school and are experiencing difficulties which may eventually result in homelessness.

What is the use of setting up excellent services if they are hamstrung, unable to cope with their case load, and raise expectations within the community only to let these people down through no fault of their own?

PARA.TAB: Nationally we have an expectation that, irrespective of where we live in this great country of ours, we can equitably access telecommunications, postal and educational services. When it comes to health and community services, it is a real lottery. It all depends on where people live. Our recommendations 7.19 and 7.20 are vital if we as a country are ever to develop an effective and responsive network to support all families. Recommendation 7.19 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth and State and Territory governments immediately establish funding arrangements for the extension of Adolescent and Family Therapy and Mediation Services in a national program as a preventive measure for young people leaving home prematurely.
Recommendation 7.20 reads:
. . . recommends that targets be established for ensuring the establishment of adequate coverage of mediation and family therapy services in all States and Territories within the next three years.

It is imperative that, as well as doing this, we establish an effective linkage between other services offered and operated by the Department of Social Security, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Attorney-General's Department, the Family Court, and state education, housing and community services departments. At present, there is no such linkage, no effective network, no safety net. There is enormous duplication and an ineffective response to this vital issue.

PARA.TAB: In the area of Commonwealth-state responsibilities for the care, support and protection of young people, it was interesting to read the initial knee-jerk response by all states and territories to the release of our report, and more especially to the nine recommendations in this section of the report. Put the states under pressure and they trot out all the defensive cliches to try to deflect any blame. States are hopelessly blinkered into a departmental territoriality syndrome. When it comes to young people, examples of interagency cooperation are a rarity.

All states have youth affairs departments, and they are almost exclusively located in the premiers' offices. They are all token efforts, having no effective liaising role, no resources, no clout when it comes to decision making. State and territory governments are responsible for child welfare but, because of Commonwealth involvement in a number of programs for families and their children, the states have sought to relinquish their responsibilities under the claim of fiscal incapacity. Services offered by state governments have been pared to the bone in the name of fiscal restraint and responsibility. Staff in these areas are inadequately trained and resourced and families in need have been extremely disadvantaged. It is interesting to note the comments in the 1989 Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report in this area which concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of State welfare and health authorities both to provide appropriate and timely assistance to families in need and to provide appropriate nurture and support to children committed to, and leaving, their care, is a serious indictment on the willingness and capacity of those authorities to properly discharge their legal and social responsibilities . . . The States are ill-equipped or unwilling to offer appropriate services . . .
Nothing, I would venture, has changed since this damning statement six years ago.

PARA.TAB: We have now been offered the magic word `protocol'. A federal-state government case management protocol for young people has been agreed to and signed by all parties. It acknowledges a shared responsibility for the welfare of children. It sounds fine in theory, but in practice out there in the real world it is a hopeless mess. It has been operating for close on a year. Our committee members were told of the following concerns in relation to the effectiveness and implementation of this protocol: the inability of state governments adequately to respond to the demands of the protocol in major cities as well as in regional areas of Australia; an increased workload generated by the protocol placing an unmanageable burden on a service already unable to meet its statutory responsibilities to young people; young people becoming further disadvantaged as a result of the cumbersome bureaucratic procedures in operation; the inadequacy of state and territory welfare departments' financial support during the risk assessment period and beyond; the lack of accountability of the states and territories for the actions taken following referral; and, lastly, the failure of the protocol to include access to education.

The area of parental roles and responsibilities is the area of our report which produced the most angst from the members of the public who made submissions to us and from members of our committee. Of course it is controversial. When state and federal government policies and programs impact on family relationships and arrangements, of course you will upset some people in our society.

The most contentious issues are access to income support and the extent to which it acts as an incentive to young people to leave home, and the supremacy of children's rights over the rights of parents. It is interesting to note that there is consensus between parent groups and community and welfare organisations on a range of other issues dealing with young people. These are: the lack of preventative and early intervention services for families and adolescents; the inadequate support offered to families by state welfare authorities; the lack of responsibility and accountability of both the Commonwealth and the state governments for the welfare of young people receiving the homeless rate of income support; the need to improve and increase the training and the skills of people working in the youth field; and the absence of adequate and accessible family support services for families and adolescents.

These issues and the other issues mentioned today are not barrows which the committee members are pushing for their own political advantage. Unless the Commonwealth and the state and territory ministers responsible for these areas bite the bullet and seriously look at the recommendations contained in our report and work tirelessly to implement them, we will end up with a situation which is evident in many other areas of the world where youth is out of control and where the services are inadequate. The punitive measures which are being forced upon these governments are far more costly and far more divisive than anything that we could ever envisage in this country.

All members of the committee worked tirelessly to produce this report, and I thank them. It is a bipartisan report with a few exceptions towards the end. I can understand the concerns of members opposite, but we can work together to implement the many recommendations in this report. I trust and hope that the families who put submissions in, the service providers who are working tirelessly for young people and the Commonwealth and state government agencies who have the responsibility to ensure that these programs work effectively will examine the recommendations so that we can come to a sensible and effective conclusion in resolving this matter.
