Consideration resumed from 30 March.
Motion (by Mr O'Keefe) agreed to:
That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to talk about the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which has recently been tabled in the parliament, entitled A report on aspects of youth homelessness. I think it is a very significant report and one to which a lot of members should address themselves, if they have a caring position for the community.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that we have a serious problem with some of our youth, although not with all of our youth, because most of our youth are quite well regarded and take their positions in the community. But we do have a serious problem with some of our youth in Australia at the moment. The facts speak loudly. The number receiving the youth homeless allowance has risen from 950 recipients to almost 10,000 in recent times. There are estimates that approximately 40,000 young people are considered homeless. This report investigated these issues and it is quite significant in some of the issues that it discusses and in its recommendations. It does not really try to seek solutions. Rather, it allows for further discussion on the whole matter of youth homelessness. It is a very important issue and is something that we, as parliamentarians, should be considering very urgently because, in my view, we have an urgent problem.

Young people have a right to a future and to have some hope in our country, and it is a major problem for a country as rich as Australia to have young people, without much hope and without much future, seeking some respite from their own family home through no fault of their own. We should be nurturing our young people, who are really the major asset of our country. We should be trying to look after them and provide a future for them. Yet we have an estimate that some 40,000 young Australians are considered homeless. I do not think it is because of poor parenting, although I believe that a lot of parenting skills are not inherent: they have to be developed and taught. Perhaps we should be considering the teaching of parenting to classes in the community. It is not that we are trying to protect these young people by institutionalising them—I do not think we should be doing that either. We should be trying to protect them, giving them some opportunity for the future, some choices that they can be making to provide a future for them.

The report discusses a lot of recommendations. However, there are a couple of things that I should comment on. One is the role of the states. In my view, in most states that we visited, not enough attention is being paid to our youth in this particular area. The particular area of 15- to 16-year-olds is a very grey area of responsibility at the federal level, and at the state level it is very grey indeed. A lot of these people who consider themselves homeless fall into this particular age group.

I also strongly suggest that we look at early intervention measures. A case recently which related to community services in New South Wales is a typical example. Unfortunately. a young child, six years of age, was beaten by his parents and died. Two weeks prior to this event, the mother contacted community services and asked for help and gave them an early warning signal, but no-one took appropriate action and we lost a young child. In this report we have identified a number of people who asked for early intervention, for some help, and the help was not available. It really is a tragedy, when families in Australia are asking for help to be able to overcome some problems they have within the family, that we are not responding quickly enough. I ask the state governments to review the whole process of how they respond to these issues.

In Melbourne, I was impressed by a parent who gave some evidence; I think she was from the Geelong area. She spoke of three types of children who are homeless. One type was the child that is abused—physically, sexually, emotionally or mentally. The second group includes the children who do not know what is going on. To use her description, they have `storms in their head'. They are going through a difficult period of growing and they are not necessarily overcoming some of the challenges facing them. Of course, the third group is those that fraudulently take advantage of the system.

The trouble with youth homelessness, I believe, is the perception in the community; and perceptions are reality as it is seen. The perception is that most homeless youth are troubled, they are taking advantage of the system, and they should go home to their parents. I have been to a public meeting and listened to parents quite dramatically and emotionally express their feelings towards government department officers. A lot of parents out there would like to have their children back. But the problem is deeper than people taking advantage of the system. There are children who are abused, and we should be responding to that. There are young people who do have problems with their families. They may perceive problems with their parents, while the parents do not perceive any problems with their children. Some do have these storms in their heads, and some are children who are defrauding the system.

This report has a problem in dealing with those three separate areas. It is very difficult to differentiate between them; and when we consider youth homelessness as an issue, too often we try to put all three groups into one bracket. It cannot be done: we have to address them as separate issues. Frankly, this particular report does not have any solutions to that, but it again reinforces the point that this whole issue needs further investigation.

As I said before, I went to a public meeting at which parents were really grieving for their children. They could not understand why their children did not want to live at home, and they could not understand why state departments were not giving information to the parents. One parent explained her situation. She and her family went along to a squat to see her 14-year-old daughter. She had been away from home for about 12 months, and in that 12 months had been raped by some of the squatters in the same place, but she was choosing to live away from home. The mother explained the story quite emotionally, saying how the child's father was on his knees pleading with her to come home.

These parents have no solution themselves, but they are grieving. I wonder whether we should be providing some sort of counselling to parents. We talk about mediation, we talk about counselling, and we talk about reconciliation and bringing these people together. But if they are not reconciled, and they will never be reconciled, there do not seem to be any counselling services available to parents—services they can actually go to and express their grief. It would be like having a death in the family to lose one of your children—a child you love and cherish. To not have the child with you any more would be like having a death in the family, and there is no counselling to assist that grieving process to take place. At this public meeting, the parents were really emotionally grieving, but there was not any help for them. So not only do we have to consider the future of the children in these particular instances; we should also be considering the parents and the families they leave behind.

We have a minority report. Most of my colleagues on this side of the House have supported the report in most of its recommendations, but there are a couple of areas that we have concerns about, and we have expressed those concerns. One is the administration of the whole process, and the other is the abuse claims. There does not seem to be any recommendation within the report about an appeal process for parents in relation to abuse. What we are suggesting is that perhaps that should be available to parents. At the moment, if a child does claim abuse, there does not seem to be any follow-up by any of the state bodies, including the police. I think any abuse should be investigated, because of other siblings who might be involved; but there is no appeal process at the moment for parents to have their day in court, and to discredit any other claims of abuse against them. So we need to look at that.

The report is a significant report. We ask for its consideration by the government. We ask for the government to respond to a number of recommendations and I hope that it does that quickly. I have had other experiences in this place and on a number of other committees. I have been waiting for some response by the government for over two years on one very important report that I am dealing with concerning another committee. I am asking the government to respond to this particular report quickly because it is a significant report. I hope it is not lost through the election debate that is going on at the moment. If we have an early election, I hope that this report does get responded to in this particular parliament. I think it should because it is quite significant.

My colleagues have mentioned the staff of the secretariat and the way they have handled the whole process of this inquiry. They have been very good at it. They have provided a lot of the information. I would also like to acknowledge my colleagues on both sides of parliament. I think they have been very compassionate in their dealings with this particular issue. It was something that was important for each of the people on the inquiry. It has shown that we as human beings are quite compassionate; we do not necessarily bring politics into our thinking all the time. I think that was shown during this whole inquiry. I would like to commend my colleagues on their attitude to the entire inquiry.

Finally, I think this is an important issue. It is something that is not going to die. Youth homelessness is a growing problem in the community. It is something we need to address quickly in order to seek some solutions. I ask the government to respond to this report and I ask the state governments to treat it with some sort of urgency as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mrs Silvia

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise as a member who took part in that youth homelessness inquiry. A report on aspects of youth homelessness is a good report because it finally lays to rest the myth that the existence of income support encourages young people to run away. I speak from absolute knowledge that young people are not, and have never been, encouraged to run away. For 10 years I worked in a family group home in Launceston and worked with many young people who could not and should not ever have had to live at home under some of the circumstances they were in. Therefore, the youth homeless allowance is of great assistance to many of our young Australians who often are in desperate and dire need of some support.

PARA.TAB: Recently, I noted that it was very good of Senator Jocelyn Newman to write to the Launceston Examiner and alert the people of Tasmania to possible fraudulent claims on the Commonwealth for youth homeless allowance applications. As honourable members know, the allowance is administered by the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training. One does wonder, however, about the motive of Jocelyn Newman. After all, there is possible fraud going on all over the place where a benefit can be obtained. There are possible fraudulent claims on many public and private institutions.

Fraud is a fairly serious business. To make allegations in a newspaper about a possible case of fraud by an unnamed young person is certainly not something to be treated lightly. According to the senator's letter in the 31 May edition of the Launceston Examiner, a conspiracy of teenagers is at work here. Let me quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The electorate of Bass has more than a quarter of all Tasmania's YHA—
youth homeless allowance—
recipients. I believe this is indicative of a `network' of teenagers who, informed of the benefits available to them (from each other and from school)—
and I assume she means the information comes from each other and through others at school—
rort the system.

DEET figures indicate that almost 400 Austudy recipients were granted the independent—that is, free of parental income test—student homeless rate in Tasmania last year. That 400 includes students to 22 years of age, which is the normal age of independence for Austudy. They are not exactly teenagers. The electorate of Bass has 100 students at that rate. There are five electorates in Tasmania so, in Senator Newman's perfect state view, Bass should have a fifth, not a quarter, of the state's share—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! I would remind honourable members that we are discussing a report, not an issue. I would ask the honourable member to come back to the precise report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the report on youth homelessness and the issue of youth homelessness was brought up in that statement in the newspaper.
—I remind the honourable member that it is not part of the report. In this Main Committee, we should stick to the non-controversial matters before us.

—Tasmania's Austudy youth homeless rate recipients resident in the Bass electorate appear to be consistent with the proportion of the state's 15- to 19-year-olds living there. Therefore, in the study and the report, we discussed what was a homeless student. In the information leaflets for students that we receive from DEET, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: You must be living away from home because . . . Your physical or mental health is at great risk because of your family situation. This could be due to domestic violence, sexual harassment, extreme family breakdown or other similar severe situations; your parents are in prison, missing or have a medical condition which means they cannot give you a home or support; you are a refugee . . .

What is distressing is the fact that the criteria are cold, harsh reflections of the reality that some students face, and I am particularly concerned about secondary age students. That was very indicative as we went around this country and listened to the submissions from people and organisations.

PARA.TAB: The student homeless rate for Austudy is not easy to get, contrary to claims. It is not very easy to get because it has to be administered fairly. The government and the bureaucracy must administer taxpayers' money fairly. I am assured that the responsible department's guidelines, through our studies, require all aspects of the case to be taken into account, with input being sought not only from students themselves but also from parents—except, of course, where contact could place the student at risk. Many examples of that were given to us. Where possible, reconciliation and continued support from parents, rather than from other taxpayers, is encouraged, as the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) discussed in his statement. He said that reconciliation is a way to assist in lessening the number of young people claiming that allowance.

The policy manual covering Austudy has 30 or 40 pages devoted to the assessment of the student homeless rate applications. Some of the committee references outlined the fact that there was no real case to be borne that public servants were not administering the policy and the correct guidelines as set down.

There is a lot of work involved in this issue. It is very sensitive and public servants also know that, with every grant or rejection of the independent rate based on extreme family circumstances, someone's nose is going to be put out of joint. What showed up through the report and the undertakings throughout the country was that, in general, everyone who was involved was bipartisan. It is rather a shame that certain people easily whip up something that is very sensitive into a greater issue without taking into account the fact that we need to look at it carefully to make sure that all our young Australians, who desperately need our guidance and assistance through allowances or subsidies, are looked after.

The case that I mentioned that was cited by Senator Newman represented the classic low act. I do not think anyone who publicises the fact that they are representing a particular person in need does that individual a favour. No rort was shown to have occurred.

When the committee invited submissions, because Senator Newman actually felt so concerned about it, we would have hoped that she would have raised those concerns with the committee, but unfortunately she was not able to be in attendance at any of the hearings. We had a very good hearing in Hobart where some 11 individuals or organisations turned up and told us in no uncertain terms of the situation in Tasmania. I was advised that Senator Newman's letter in the Launceston Examiner appeared only a matter of a few days after she wrote to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free), so there had not been enough time for a reply.

As a member of the committee looking into youth homelessness, I found it rather disturbing that a single case in the northern part of Tasmania, in my electorate, had been publicly discussed and had not been brought to our committee for discussion. I and no doubt every other member of the House would agree that Austudy should not be made available to students who simply are not getting on with their parents, or to students who are rorting the system, or to students who are fraudulently claiming circumstances which might qualify them for Austudy. I hope that every member would also condemn the way in which any other member would use this issue to promote suspicion and distrust of the way that student assistance is being administered. That is there to help the young homeless people to continue their lives and to help them continue their education. From past experience in working with those people for 10 years, I know that they have often found themselves in appalling and disgusting circumstances at that stage of their life.

This is a good report. It recognises the sensitivity of these situations. It places a great deal of emphasis on case review, which itself will go a long way to foster reconciliation where possible. Most importantly, this report calls on the states to play their roles and to accept their responsibilities on these issues. The Commonwealth is essentially the financing agent for the program and is not equipped to play the enforcement role. The Commonwealth-state liaison must be addressed to achieve increased efficiency in delivery of the system.

The report also deals with children under 16 being referred to refuges as step one rather than receiving the benefit. These are sound and well thought out recommendations to deal with a very difficult and a very sensitive problem. This report represents a pro-active approach, unlike writing to a local newspaper in an endeavour to score some cheap political points.

Before I close, I would also like to pass my thanks to the chairman of the committee, the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), who is present, and to all my fellow committee members. A special thanks also must go to Bjarne Nordin, Peta Fitzgibbon, Lynette Sebo and Jodie Williams from the secretariat for their hard work, assistance and guidance. It was certainly much appreciated. I would also like to publicly thank the 19 individuals and 130-plus organisations, 11 of those from Tasmania, who took the time to offer their submissions to the committee. I would like to say that their thoughts, their ideas and their suggestions throughout those hearings were much appreciated. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This report from the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on aspects of youth homelessness has in fact been tabled in the House and I have spoken on it in the chamber. This morning I just wish to add a few comments to the remarks that I had made that day. As we know, times for consideration of reports are short and this report is in fact very long. The report contains 129 recommendations. I touched on some of those in my earlier remarks, and I would like to go to a few more of them now.

PARA.TAB: The first one I want to touch on is the fact that many people in submissions raised the question of some form of temporary payment for young people who are homeless or being evicted or being left stranded in traumatic circumstances and then it taking a substantial time for them to find some form of support. That is certainly a serious issue that we should be aware of. But at the same time there was a concern that that may well lead to frauding or to the allowance and support being diminished or demeaned in the minds of the community.

We therefore recommended that the applicants should be dealt with very quickly. In other words, if the government could not respond within a day or a day and a half or so of an application, that was the government's fault and not the applicant's fault, remembering that in the report we recommend that all such applicants should have face to face assessment by a professional social worker and that it not be done by telephone or some other form of correspondence. I will come back to that in a moment.

We have recommended therefore a probationary period for the allowance, so that within six weeks of the first payment being given the department would be required to review whether that payment should be sustained, and the review would be required to be substantiated with a case plan. I am not wishing to use the words `case management' there but `case plan' to make sure that we have taken into account the person's circumstances: home life, relationship with families, schooling and accommodation. So rather than simply granting an allowance and leaving it at that we recognise that the money is not usually the major problem; it is very often the other aspect, the support, that a young person needs.

The first six weeks is the best possible chance for reconciliation with families. In that context the other raft of support measures such as extended families comes into play. A young person being fostered by a stranger is giving more support to that family than if it is some relation. In other words, we may well be able to find in that first six weeks, in that probationary period, alternative arrangements that offer more than money but rather offer support for that young person. That probationary period is a fundamental shift in concept because it indicates to the young person and to the family that the payment is not a permanent process but rather a means towards establishing a better long-term circumstance. That long-term circumstance may well be independent living or it may be reconciliation. There is a range of choices. The way that it has operated to date has been very black and white: if a person receives a payment, someone is making a permanent judgment about him or her and/or the family, and that is not helpful.

Going further in terms of the alternatives available, the honourable member for Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith) spoke just briefly about refuges. The fact is that as a government, with the agreement of state governments, we do not allow special refuges for young people under the age of 16 years. We accept that they can go to a youth refuge as a matter of crisis or a matter of urgency, but we do not accept that refuges are solely for under-16-year-olds.

That really does pose a major problem. What we are facing around Australia is effectively a lack of alternative care. We were told by state departments that adolescents of 13, 14 or 15 years age who may have had behavioural problems, who may have had problems at school, who may have had problems with family breakdowns, are hard to foster.

In addition, with the reduction in the number of state institutions—and institutional care is not the appropriate form anyhow—we are finding a very big gap in community support. Refuges are not a good place for young people to go to. The age group for youth refuges is notionally 12 to 14 years of age, so we may have a 13-year-old or 14-year-old who has just left home under extremely traumatic circumstances in a crisis situation housed on a temporary basis with young offenders, people in their early 20s in very difficult circumstances. In the same way as gaols are not necessarily a good place to send people for relatively minor offences, the refuge situation is not advisable.

That point of view came through from the whole community. Refuge workers were telling us that they should not be taking in 16-year-olds and 14-year-olds and 13-year-olds because it is not an appropriate environment. So we have suggested that the state and Commonwealth governments should explore an alternative form of SAAP which focuses on younger people.

Some form of community living, where people can live in a community context but with a home style environment, is required. Some states have played with the idea of community housing but, quite frankly, we could not find enough examples to justify using them as a model. They were too discrete and too narrow, if you like, for us to say that they would be suitable across the country. At the same time as we had the Commonwealth and states saying that they would not have SAAP accommodation solely for under-16-year-olds, which is an acceptance of the fact that it is not appropriate, we had the refuge in Western Australia that I mentioned where five of the six young people staying there were under 16. In other words, five-sixths of them were under 16. The reality is that an enormous number of young people are going into refuges because they have nowhere else. There is a desperate need for SAAP to be refocused. The report strongly urges the state and Commonwealth governments to review that situation and to perhaps look at some SAAP accommodation services that would be for under 16-year-olds but different from what we have now.

Another point that we need to perhaps emphasise more strongly is the question of psychiatric illness, its prevalence and how it is treated. The report quotes the evidence of Professor Kosky, who was an extremely valuable witness to the inquiry. He had a great deal to offer in this area. He pointed out that about half of all psychiatric illnesses are diagnosed by the age of 19 and that the median age for half of those diagnosed mental disorders is 16 years. The under-20 age group receives about seven per cent of the funding. Adults make the decisions about the budget but it is that younger age group where there is an enormously high level of psychiatric disorders. The budget that goes towards that group is in fact is very low and quite disparate.

At the same time, with the deinstitutionalisation of psychiatric institutions that has been occurring, we are finding fewer and fewer resources available. The capacity for youth workers to diagnose whether a person has a behavioural problem or a psychiatric problem is minimal. There is no training available. These youth workers are not trained in that way. In fact, in the Northern Territory, we found that there are no psychiatrists, so people could not be diagnosed. There is a failure by governments, state and federal, to recognise that psychiatric illness is a major issue with young people. The illness is both undiagnosed and untreated. It is certainly that group which provides the major source of homelessness.

Professor Kosky also made the very valid point—I do not think anybody else raised it—that, in many cases, a young person with a psychiatric problem, which may be developing even before they reach their teens, will be seen as having a behavioural problem. Because the illness happens gradually and develops over time, the family will accommodate it and it often leads to a family breakdown. So, rather than the homelessness being a result of family breakdown, the family breakdown may be a result of a psychiatric illness that is not diagnosed. The parents, the family and teachers see it as a behavioural problem. They see the child as being wayward, undisciplined, uncontrollable, all of those terms that we use.

In fact, Professor Kosky pointed out that in many families one parent will often take the side of the child and the other parent will not. It is that difference which often breaks up the family itself. Undiagnosed psychiatric illness of some young Australians is leading to family breakdown, which, in turn, leads to homelessness. Lack of perception and understanding of that is a major problem. This whole area is ignored. So when we talk about training our youth workers we are not talking simply about training in counselling. We are talking about training in recognising that a young person may not have a behavioural problem but may have a psychiatric problem which, if treated and dealt with, may mean that person can be restored not just to the community but to his or her family.

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having being called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 11.07 a.m. to 11.21 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to touch briefly on a couple more things in the short time available. The first one is the question of schools as a place for early intervention and early recognition of a young person—and, in many cases, a family—experiencing trauma. It has been raised with me that teachers are trained to teach people, and that is certainly the case; but teachers are also very aware when their students are in difficulty or their performance changes dramatically over a short time. The fact is that in most cases they have no-one that they can refer to, because our systems are so caught up with crises.

PARA.TAB: What we need to see is a much closer partnership between the education system and the community services sector—and, in some cases, the health sector—so that when a teacher perceives that a pupil is in difficulty there can be a very quick response at that very early stage. The way to address this problem is to try to prevent it occurring in the first place. Homelessness is not always preventable, but it certainly can be diminished from what it is now. That would require intervention and family support much earlier than we currently have it.

One of the vehicles that we propose in the report is the use of the auditing provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. That is being put forward as a vehicle for premiers and prime ministers to start to look at policies on children and the family as one policy—across, between and within governments. Within any one government we may have five or six ministers and departments all covering this area. In the states we have health, education and community services and juvenile justice departments all involved in some way. When looking at state and federal ministers combined, we may have 30 or 40 ministers involved, and their areas are treated as separate issues. We are arguing that there should be one policy within each government—one policy for each state government and one policy for the federal government—and they should be coherent. Rather than it being the responsibility of junior ministers and a junior part of their portfolios, it should be seen as being a problem for premiers and prime ministers as a major national focus.

We put those structural changes forward because they really do need talking about. This report is not the end of the story: it is a vehicle for consultation and discussion. I expect that in the next few months the youth sector and the community sector across Australia will start to talk about this issue in a different way. We have tried to produce a report that they can work with and work their way through. I am urging governments of all persuasions and at all levels to listen to that debate, to listen to the community, and to watch their response to this report. The report may not have all the answers, or even the best answers, but it is a vehicle to help find some of the best answers for the sake of those 22,000 to 30,000 young people. They need much more than simply reports; they need some actions.

During the inquiry we had a lot of help from a lot of people, and I want to make sure that that is recognised. In the months ahead we want those same people to stay engaged. They became part of the inquiry, and they are part of the report. This report is tabled by the committee, but it belongs to a lot of people. All those people who took part in the inquiry are now part of the result of it, and I encourage them to stay in support of this issue.
